head.title: Informing library-based digital publishing: Selected findings from a survey of scholars' needs in a contemporary publishing environment | Digital Scholarship in the Humanities | Oxford Academic

div.h1: Informing library-based digital publishing: Selected findings from a survey of scholars' needs in a contemporary publishing environment

div.div:
School of Information Sciences, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign,
USA

Correspondence: Megan Senseney, School of Information Sciences, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, 501 East Daniel Street, MC-493, Champaign, IL, 61820-6211, USA. E-mail:mfsense2@illinois.edu

Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 34, Issue Supplement_1, December 2019, Pages i172–i178, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqy052

div.p: Megan Senseney, Maria Bonn, Christoper Maden, Janet Swatscheno, LaTesha Velez, Harriett Green, Katrina Fenlon, Informing library-based digital publishing: Selected findings from a survey of scholars' needs in a contemporary publishing environment, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 34, Issue Supplement_1, December 2019, Pages i172–i178, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqy052

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: Library-based publishing initiatives are on the rise in a rapidly diversifying scholarly publishing ecosystem. This article presents selected results from a US-based survey on the needs of humanities scholars in a contemporary publishing environment, emphasizing survey responses that shed light on key aspects of access for scholars seeking to publish: access to support services, access to content, and access to audience. Survey responses suggest a profile of the authors for whom libraries are poised to offer attractive publishing solutions: (1) those whose scholarship is not sufficiently represented in the print medium and (2) those who place a high value on the technological affordances provided by open-access digital scholarship to reach their intended audiences. Compared to other publishing models, situating support for scholarly communication in the research library creates opportunities for addressing challenges related to access and sustainability in the digital scholarly publishing.

div.p: The scholarly publishing landscape is rapidly diversifying. As publishing options proliferate, scholars must align their choices with their overarching goals. The relationship between faculty needs and values in scholarly communication requires concerted scrutiny, particularly around models for digital publishing and strategies for preservation and sustainability (Harley et al., 2010). Open-access publishing has emerged as a scholarly strategy that prioritizes audience reach and, in turn, increases the impact of scholarship (Fitzpatrick, 2012). When access as a value of scholarship is foregrounded in publishing, academic libraries emerge as ‘natural and efficient loci for scholarly publication’ (Courant and Jones, 2015). In a rapidly evolving digital publishing landscape, academic libraries are poised to address scholars’ publishing concerns about providing open access to intellectual content and ensuring access to the audiences who will most benefit from their work. The growth of library-based publishing services is demonstrated by the 125 college and university libraries currently listed in the Library Publishing Directory (Library Publishing Coalition, 2018), but further research is required to better understand that role of libraries within the broader publishing landscape. This article presents selected results from a US-based survey on the needs of humanities scholars in a contemporary publishing environment, emphasizing aspects of the survey responses that shed light on key aspects of access for scholars seeking to publish: access to support services, access to content, and access to audience. The survey was conducted by Publishing Without Walls (PWW), a Mellon-funded initiative at the University of Illinois led by the University Library in partnership with the School of Information Sciences, the Department of African American Studies, and the Illinois Program for Research in the Humanities. Our project is developing an innovative and experimental library-based digital scholarly publishing model that aims to be accessible, scalable, and sustainable.

Our objective is to develop a model for library-based publishing services that can be adopted broadly by other academic libraries to address scholars’ emerging needs in a contemporary publishing environment. The model itself places humanities scholars at the center of the ecosystem, with services informed by—and responsive to—scholars’ needs. This survey is the first part of a multi-modal research initiative designed to better understand known gaps within the current landscape: (1) the gap between what and how scholars want to publish and what existing systems of print publishing can accommodate and (2) the gap between the everyday practices of humanities scholars and high-level tools that exist for producing and supporting digital scholarship. Academic libraries are poised to address scholars’ publishing concerns about gaining access to opportunities for support and re-skilling, providing open access to their intellectual content, and ensuring access to a wide range of audiences. PWW self-consciously focuses on upholding the values of open-access scholarship and supporting experimental forms of scholarly communication.

The survey aims to understand what and how scholars want to publish, when and why they choose to publish digitally, and how they perceive the success of their digital publications. Survey outcomes will directly inform the development of PWW’s shareable service model, but we also anticipate that our survey results will be relevant to digital humanists and other scholars engaged in digital scholarly publishing, whether such efforts are located within or beyond an academic library. The project team defines digital publishing as the creation and distribution of works primarily intended for digital representation, but for the purposes of the survey the term ‘digital publication’ remained intentionally broad, which allowed us to assess respondents’ perceptions of publishing at varying levels of formality and complexity.

The survey was developed by the PWW Research Team in Spring 2016 and comprised twenty-nine questions covering six broad themes: respondents’ experiences with print and digital publishing, respondents’ publishing objectives, publishing tools and platforms, publishing services and support, publishing from the scholars’ perspective of reader as opposed to author, and general attitudes toward print and digital publishing. Using a purposive sampling method, the survey was distributed through listservs and social media venues targeting scholars in the humanities generally as well as selected niche communities to encourage sufficient responses across disciplines and institutions. The survey was open from June to October 2016 and received 250 responses. The majority of the 119 respondents who supplied optional demographics are tenure-line faculty (66%), and disciplinary representation is skewed toward English literature (30%) and Library and Information Science (19%). The team used Qualtrics to present the survey and conduct initial analysis. Preliminary findings have been reported previously (Fenlon et al., 2016), and a question-by-question survey report with descriptive statistics has been archived in IDEALS, the institutional repository of the University of Illinois (PWW Research Team, 2017).

Respondents were asked to identify which aspects of publishing posed the most significant challenges with respect to their experiences with print and digital content. Figure 1 represents the percentage of respondents who indicated each potential issue as either ‘quite challenging’ or ‘extremely challenging’ in print or digital publishing. The top three challenges for digital publishing include getting adequate technical, editorial, and financial support for publication. Respondents were also asked to indicate and rank their top five publishing goals, which are illustrated in Fig. 2 as a weighted average. The top four goals are consistent with the traditional expectations for scholarly publishing: contributing new information to one’s field, encouraging and participating in dialogue about an area of study, establishing a formal record of one’s scholarship, and establishing one’s reputation in the field. Audience reach is less frequently cited, but seventy-seven respondents (47%) selected it, and 36% of those who did ranked it as first or second priority. Figure 3 illustrates the top three audiences that scholars indicated they most wish to reach. The top two audiences relate to peers within the academic community. While interest in reaching the general educated reader and students is less frequently cited, it is sufficiently robust to consider how reaching these audiences may have an impact on scholars’ decision-making with regard to the medium they choose and the venues they seek for publication. Understanding how less traditional, but still prevalent, publishing goals affect these choices is also a potentially fruitful avenue for exploring how explicitly stated publishing objectives inform, and possibly shift, priorities regarding representation and dissemination within scholarly publishing. Figure 4 is a cross-tabulated view comparing a scholar’s top-ranked publishing goals with their top-ranked criteria for selecting a publishing medium, and Fig. 5 is a cross-tabulated view comparing a scholar’s top-ranked publishing goals with their top-ranked criteria for selecting a publishing venue. These figures illustrate how specific publishing goals affect scholars’ choices in selecting a medium and venue. Questions about medium have to do with format, whereas questions about venue probe respondents’ criteria in selecting a given publisher. When asked what kinds of content are typically present in their scholarly work, the most common responses mapped to the affordance of traditional print media: long-form prose (88%) and figures, images, or illustrations (69%). However, a sizable minority also indicated less traditional forms of presentation, including curated research collections and archives (33%), data sets (29%), interactive visualizations (27%), and multimedia (25%). In an environment where authors incorporate more diverse technologies into their scholarly publishing, the medium’s ability to represent the work ranks fairly high in authors’ criteria when choosing how to publish.

div.p: Primary goals’ effect on venue priorities

When comparing scholars’ characterization of challenges in digital versus print publishing, speed to publication and reaching one’s intended audience emerge as the two greatest challenges to print publication, but they are perceived as relatively less challenging in digital formats. This difference between print and digital suggests that these ‘challenges’ might be considered the primary ‘affordances’ that scholars perceive for digital publishing. For digital publishing, the top three challenges that scholars face all relate to receiving adequate support for the logistical aspects of the process, including technical, editorial, and financial support. Though not one of the top three challenges, another aspect of publication that the survey responses suggest is more challenging in digital than print publication is manuscript preparation. Respondents’ emphasis on support services indicates the importance of publishers’ early intervention in digital publications. Despite the fact that the most prevalent challenges in digital publishing relate to issues of support, the support that scholars will receive from publishers never emerges as a major factor in a scholar’s choice of publishing medium or venue, regardless of their specific publication goals and intended audiences. Similarly, time to publication was considered a major challenge in print publication (and a possible affordance of digital publication), but it does not appear to be a prominent deciding factor in selecting a venue. Understanding these challenges provides library-based publishers with an opportunity to add value to the digital publishing experience, but these are not likely to be deciding factors in an author’s choice to publishing within this framework.

The top three considerations with respect to choosing both one’s medium and the venue in which to publish are the ability to effectively represent the scholarship, the ability to reach one’s target audience, and the reputation or prestige of the venue or medium. The weight of these and remaining factors, however, shifts when analyzed in conjunction with a scholar’s primary publishing goals, suggesting opportunities for publishers to develop more nuanced consultative support services for selecting publishing tools and platforms. Survey results are consistent with our expectations regarding the relative importance of prestige for professional development, which diminishes as goals shift toward broader audiences. About one-third of respondents consistently indicated the importance of the medium’s ability to represent the scholarship, which suggests this is a key reason for choosing digital publishing regardless of one’s primary objective. For venue, the publisher’s reputation is most important when establishing one’s own reputation in the field but also in establishing a formal record of one’s scholarship. Access becomes more prominent as authors express interest in audience reach and encouraging the application of their work in practice. Identifying projects with the dual goal of practical application and broad readership may prove especially useful acquisition strategy library-based publishers. Publications developed with these motivations stand to benefit from libraries’ pre-existing strengths while experiencing fewer drawbacks associated with publishers whose reputations are less established.

Audience and representation are most likely to be the determining factor in a scholar’s decision to shift away from traditional print publishing and to consider library-based digital publishing opportunities. The continued emphasis on reputation and prestige, however, may prove problematic for fledgling initiatives that seek to develop alternatives to established publication models such as those of university presses. Further research will investigate what constitutes acceptable markers of prestige, such as the affiliation with an institution of higher education, which libraries already have, or affiliation with known university presses, which most libraries do not have.

Situating support for publishing in the research library creates possibilities for addressing challenges related to access and sustainability of digital scholarship. Publishing support can be performed efficiently as a part of library activities, leveraging pre-existing technical infrastructure that is designed to support discovery and preservation as well as digital scholarship programs. These aspects of library-based publishing prove especially compelling in light of survey findings that the biggest challenges for digital publishing include securing adequate technical support services, in addition to financial and editorial support.

These results represent a small fraction of the overall survey, but they are particularly informative when seeking to situate library-based digital scholarly publishing within the broader publishing ecosystem where the objective is to open new avenues for publication to scholars whose needs are not currently being met by traditional press or commercial publications. The PWW initiative is seeking to offer attractive solutions for authors (1) whose scholarship is not sufficiently represented in the print medium and (2) who place a high value on the technological affordances provided by open access digital scholarship to reach their intended audiences. We further anticipate that developing value-added support services in the form of individual consultation and incubation workshops will help ease the support-related challenges cited by scholars, particularly when assessing which platforms and tools will best represent an author’s scholarship.
This work was supported by a grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation [grant number 31500644].
